Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Situation2: A passenger who booked through the app is waiting and urgently pressing for a quicker arrival.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the screen split between two worlds. On one side, my colleague’s message blinked: “Can you send the report by noon? I need it to finish my part.” I knew the whole team was waiting on me, and any delay would throw off the project timeline. On the other side, the taxi app pinged again—my next passenger, already waiting, sent another message: “Please hurry, I have a flight in an hour.” I could almost feel their impatience through the screen.

My laptop was open on the passenger seat, the report half-finished. I’d promised myself I’d get it done before my shift, but the morning rush had been relentless. Now, I was parked at the curb, torn. If I took a few more minutes to finish the report, I’d be late picking up the passenger, risking a bad review and maybe even a complaint. But if I left now, the report would be late, letting down my colleague and the team. My hands gripped the steering wheel, heart pounding, as I weighed the expectations pressing in from both sides, unsure which responsibility to put first.
